148.title: Our Boarding House
148.author: Gene Ahern
148.series: Jan. 27, 1922) "Mrs. Hoople's Globe Trotting Husband Comes Back Home!"
148.appears_in: reprinted on p. 9 of The World of Comic Art, v. 2, no. 3 (1970).
notes: Summary: Martha and a houseful of boarders greet Amos, who has been "gone nigh on ten years!"
Editor's note says this is the "first appearance of Major Amos Barnaby Hoople."

149.title: Our Boarding House
149.author: Gene Ahern.
149.series: 1927) Our Boarding House with Major Hoople, 1927

150.title: Our Boarding House
150.author: Gene Ahern.
notes: Summary: The plan is to get Abe Getz, the costume renter, to outfit David as a titled Britisher so Martha will accept him as a house guest.

151.title: Our Boarding House
151.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: In his loud talking, David sounds British; in his whispering between the lines he consults the Major about his disguise, and asks about how to wear the monocle.

152.title: Our Boarding House
152.author: [No author]
152.series: Dec. 30, 1937) "He'll Really Set Sail for the Owls Club"
notes: Summary: Jason announces what he thinks is a bill collector, and Amos says to say he's left on a scientific voyage to the Saragossa Sea.

153.title: Our Boarding House
153.author: [No author]
153.series: June 19, 1942) "He Flies Just Like a Wild Duck"
notes: Summary: Amos is flying his father's helicopter after only one lesson, and the boarders wonder if he can land without digging an oil well; until then they're keeping their pogo sticks.

154.title: Our Boarding House
154.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Amos suggests that his dad take a jaunt in his helicopter to get his mind off Miss Frankey, and dad suggests a fishing trip.

155.title: Our Boarding House
155.author: [No author]
155.series: June 17, 1943) "That Puts 'em in the Pan with the Fish"*
notes: Summary: The boarders were worried and come looking for Amos, and find him cooking fish in his campsite. He offers them a helicopter ride.

156.title: Our Boarding House
156.author: [No author]
156.series: Mar. 3, 1944) "Mack Said Seaweed, Jake, Rubber Trees!"
notes: Summary: The major asks about tapioca: "Is it a fruit or vegetable, and does it come for a bush, tree or plant?"

157.title: Our Boarding House
157.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Amos and Jake are thinking up schemes to decide who will be Pike's bodyguard.

158.title: Our Boarding House
158.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Amos and Jake are painting the house at what they think is breakneck speed; Martha calls them turtles.

159.title: Our Boarding House
159.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Pop arrives for a visit and sees Amos and Jake painting the house, albeit not very energetically.

160.title: Our Boarding House
160.author: [No author]
160.series: June 12, 1945) "Unpack, Dad, and Have a Cup of Tea"
notes: Summary: The elder Hoople begins his visit by handing Martha $100 "for steering my son Amos away from the men with the butterfly nets all these years."

161.title: Our Boarding House
161.author: [No author]
161.series: July 6, 1945) Original comic art : sample collection of artwork for various U.S. comic strips.
notes: ca. 40 items in box 63 x 53 x 9 cm.
Assembled from various acquisitions of the Russel B. Nye Popular Culture Collection at the Michigan State University Libraries .
The Wizard of Id (Brant Parker & Johnny Hart), 1/4/?? (Sunday). 1. Newspaper comic strips. I. [Each strip title and date]. II. [Each creator] Call no.: oversize PN6726 .O7

162.title: Our Boarding House
162.author: [No author]
162.series: July 30, 1945) "Well, They Stuck Out Their Chins"
notes: Summary: Mack and Buster tease Hoople about his inventing, asking if he's invented a magnetic keyhole, and he says he's sold his crime detector "at a fancy figure."

163.title: Our Boarding House
163.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: On the golf course, Amos and his father trade stories about wind: This is stagnant air! the windmills in Australia got so hot they pumped steam; in Kansas the wind made flying ducks stand still.

164.title: Our Boarding House
164.author: [No author]
164.series: Jan. 7, 1950) "Coming in for an Emergency Landing"*
notes: Summary: Uncle Bulgy falls down while ice skating; a bystander isn't concerned: "That old duffer is well padded!"

165.title: Our Boarding House
165.author: [No author]
165.series: Apr. 1, 1950) "Has He a Good Strong Forearm?"*
notes: Summary: Amos is bringing his wrestler for a meal, as he's "drooling for a match with the muffins." Martha agrees to it, mentioning South Pacific.

166.title: Our Boarding House
166.author: [No author]
166.series: Apr. 11, 1950) "Hail the King of the Arctic Circle"
notes: Summary: Kukulik was being "batted around like a badminton bird," then suddenly won the wrestling match with a hold called an Iceland Sling.

167.title: Our Boarding House
167.author: [No author]
167.series: Oct. 3, 1950) "Surprise! It Looks Like a Sale"
notes: Summary: The Major is selling books on a doorstep, and the pitch includes Shakespeare, Poe, "famed atomic scientists," and Mozart. The customer responds talking about Moliere's Republic of Letters.

168.title: Our Boarding House
168.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Amos is writing a spring song at the piano, that will drown out Mendelssohn. Martha wants to know, given a world of atom bombs, cold war, hot war, reds, jets, taxes and tanks, if the vernal equinox has cracked his bell.

169.title: Our Boarding House
169.author: [No author]
169.series: Mar. 22, 1951) "The Old Boy is Strictly Not Neutral"
notes: Summary: The Major assaults a stranger in the park after hearing him say the fight against communism is lost; "are we outguessed by a bevy of Volga boatmen?"
Key words: Spirit of '76, flintlocks, Cornwallis, Russians.

170.title: Our Boarding House
170.author: [No author]
170.series: Mar. 27, 1951) "This Meeting Won't Get Any Space In Pravda"
notes: Summary: The Major makes a speech to the Owls Club, about the morale of America being poisoned; the audience compares Stalin to their wives and communism to all the cop raids they've been through.

171.title: Our Boarding House
171.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Martha reads the Major's essay, and speaks of the patriotism of her folks, the one-shot Rathbuns of Kentucky; he wishes she could be smuggled into the Kremlin with a mop.
Key words: Russia, courage, tigresses, typewriters.

172.title: Our Boarding House
172.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Major Hoople's two-paragraph patriotic essay appears on page one of the newspaper, though Twiggs wants to know how he kept it so short; the reader knows that it was originally 14 pages.

173.title: Our Boarding House
173.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: The Civil Defense Committee appoints Major Hoople the auxiliary Fire Chief, and Martha says it's the kind of Sitting Bull operation that should fit him like a nightgown.

174.title: Our Boarding House
174.author: [No author]
174.series: Apr. 25, 1951) "The Arena Just Before the First Punch was Thrown" *
notes: Summary: The Major's work as an umpire leads to a series of threats and put-downs.
Key words: Hanging, for two cents I'd, grinders, meatheads, bats, false teeth.

175.title: Our Boarding House
175.author: [No author]
175.series: Apr. 26, 1951) "Hard Fight Mom, I'll Be Right Home"
notes: Summary: Afterwards the boys bring Uncle Bulgy home in a wagon, and the Major's head is spinning as he asks the conductor to refer to him at the iron curtain as a Ukrainian samovar salesman. A passer-by thinks he's drunk.
Key words: Spectators, hail on a tin roof, punches, sponges.

176.title: Our Boarding House
176.author: [No author]
176.series: May 26, 1951) "It's the Married Men who Object"*
notes: Summary: Belasco flashed a bale of treasury hay at Waldo's place trying to rent a room, and Waldo had to tell the Missus he was a typhoid carrier to get rid of him.

177.title: Our Boarding House
177.author: [No author]
177.series: June 28, 1951) "But You're Not Laughing Very Hard Now"
notes: Summary: The major has invested in paper socks, and says the boarders are "the kind of critics who scoffed at Ben Franklin's lightning rod." He'll laugh when the dividends come in.

178.title: Our Boarding House
178.author: [No author]
178.series: Aug. 1, 1951) "How About Lending Us Some Fried Chicken, Too?"
notes: Summary: Amos tells a farmer he's polling the rural folk on the atom bomb and foreign policy, and asks if he has any extra beds; the farmer lends him a shack and some cots.

179.title: Our Boarding House
179.author: [No author]
179.series: Aug. 2, 1951) "You'll Have to Guess Who's Talking"
notes: Summary: One voice compares sleeping on the cots to sleeping on a waffle iron; the other brags he slept on stalagmites in Mesopotamia for a fortnight.

180.title: Our Boarding House
180.author: [No author]
180.series: Aug. 15, 1951) "Little Stories Told to the Nose"
notes: Summary: Amos, Jason and Twiggs are looking down at a cabin in the mountains, and smelling food and drink.

181.title: Our Boarding House
181.author: [No author]
181.series: Sept. 5, 1951) "That Makes It All Even on Snubs"
notes: Summary: The Major is 'puffing a butt that looks like it was bought,' so two of the boarders hit him up for loans; all three are smoking.

182.title: Our Boarding House
182.author: [No author]
182.series: Dec. 5, 1951) "Say! Is This Getting to be a Fowl Act?"
notes: Summary: Comedy rehearsal. Pike does a gag about bores and parties, and a duck flies out from under Carp's hat. Twiggs says that's a paralyzer.

183.title: Our Boarding House
183.author: [No author]
183.series: Dec. 11, 1951) "Call the Doctor, and put Pike under Ether"
notes: Key words: Appendicitis, toadstools, thermometers, jests, symptoms.

184.title: Our Boarding House
184.author: [No author]
184.series: Dec. 12, 1951) "What Do You Mean You Never Played Comedy Parts?"
notes: Summary: Carp has appendicitis, and though he's a Shakespearean actor the Major volunteers to stand in for Pike's Christmas shows.

185.title: Our Boarding House
185.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: The major has dreamed he was nominated to run for president, and Twiggs thinks he's heavy enough to start a landslide.

186.title: Our Boarding House
186.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Hoople is hiding from the public because he has been bitten on the nose by a baby in his political campaign, and Twiggs says he been "as hard to find as a Republican button in Alabama."

187.title: Our Boarding House
187.author: [No author]
187.series: Sept. 16, 1952) "Great Mind Groping for the Light"
notes: Summary: Amos talks about inventing a sailor hat that sends up distress signal rockets, and Twiggs asks about his other idea for a lapel flower that squirts tear gas at holdup men.

188.title: Our Boarding House
188.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Hoople is a Justice of the Peace, and the Owls Club elected him. Now there's a demand to raid the place, and he doesn't want to be a Benedict Arnold. Twiggs comments while playing solitaire.
Our Boarding House (Dec. 4, 1952) "Schooling the Boys for a Raid" (Our Boarding House, Dec. 4, 1952)
Summary: The Owls Club plans to be discussing exploration for minerals, and As You Like It, when the police arrive.

190.title: Our Boarding House
190.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Amos has just finished Romeo and Juliet and is starting on Hamlet, and Martha wonders if he's really crazy or just acting.

191.title: Our Boarding House
191.author: [No author]
191.series: Jan. 14, 1954) "As a Matter of Fact, the Brace is News to Him"
notes: Summary: Amos presents drawings of his coat with the built-in chair, and the boarders point out a structural difficulty.

192.title: Our Boarding House
192.author: [No author]
192.series: May 6, 1954) "Practicing the Approach on Baxter's Carrots"
notes: Summary: Amos talks about his ancestor, Angus McQuarrie Hoople, who taught King James the game of golf in Scotland ; the neighbor wants him to stop tramping through his garden retrieving the ball.

193.title: Our Boarding House
193.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: The Major is in trouble for picking up somebody else's golf ball.

194.title: Our Boarding House
194.author: [No author]
194.series: May 13, 1954) "No More Than Three Balls, That Is"
notes: Summary: The Major reports on his preparations for the golf tournament; he played a difficult dogleg hole with no more than three.

195.title: Our Boarding House
195.author: [No author]
195.series: July 7, 1954) "Hercules Didn't Get That Way Cooking"
notes: Summary: The Major reads about a mountain retreat where he could relax, and Burke could get into shape, like Hercules. Burke likes cooking, fishing and swimming.

196.title: Our Boarding House
196.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Amos 'slept like a hypnotized stooge in a furniture store window;' Burke invites him to slay a caribou for breakfast.

197.title: Our Boarding House
197.author: [No author]
197.series: Sept. 17, 1954) "A Vacation Costs Us 11 Months of Putting Our Dessert in a Pig Bank"*
notes: Summary: The Major brags about catching a criminal and getting a reward, and the boarders complain about his luck.

198.title: Our Boarding House
198.author: [No author]
198.series: Oct. 30, 1954) "This is Only the First Inning, Martha"
notes: Summary: The Major has apparently begun a painting of Shakespeare.

199.title: Our Boarding House
199.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Martha shows Amos's portrait of Shakespeare to Mrs. Snackleby. Neither woman appreciates it, but neither says so out loud.

200.title: Our Boarding House
200.author: [No author]
200.series: Nov. 16, 1954) "This Knocks Leander and Alvin for a Loop"
notes: Summary: The Major shows off $100 that he got for his portrait of Shakespeare.

201.title: Our Boarding House
201.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Leander defaced the painting with a big mustache, and he can't sleep for wondering how Uncle Bulgy sold the portrait of Shakespeare after that.

202.title: Our Boarding House
202.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: The portrait of Shakespeare, as defaced by Leander, looks exactly like Bascom O'Hare the bar owner.

203.title: Our Boarding House
203.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Jake Hoople arrives and asks where the old parlor ornament (his brother) is; Martha tells him Amos is working.

204.title: Our Army at War
notes: War comic book that ran several features including Sgt. Rock (1959-1977) and Battle Album
